turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Corporate spin-off.
turn.1: What is meant by a spin-off with regards to shareholders?
turn.2: For example, when Agilent Technologies was spun off from Hewlett-Packard in 1999, the stock holders of HP received Agilent stock.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: A company not considered a spin-off in the SEC's definition (but considered by the SEC as a technology transfer or licensing of technology to the new company) may also be called a spin-off in common usage.
turn.5: What is the most common usage?
turn.6: A second definition of a spin-out is a firm formed when an employee or group of employees leaves an existing entity to form an independent start-up firm.
turn.7: Where do the employees come from?
turn.8: The prior employer can be a firm, a university, or another organization.
turn.9: Is there any other interesting aspects?
turn.10: Spin-outs typically operate at arm's length from the previous organizations and have independent sources of financing, products, services, customers, and other assets.
turn.11: Is it possible to restructure the company?
turn.12: In some cases, the spin-out may license technology from the parent or supply the parent with products or services; conversely, they may become competitors.
